citation.article-title: Archaeoglobus fulgidus gen. nov., sp. nov.: a new taxon of extremely thermophilic archaebacteria.

p.s: Archaeoglobus (Arch.ae.o.glo'bus Gr. masc. adj. archaios ancient; L. masc. n. globus sphere; M. L. masc. n. Archaeoglobus, the ancient sphere)
Regular to irregular coccoid cells, about 0.4 to 1 μn width, monopolar polytrichous flagellated.
Greenish-black smooth colonies of 1-2 mm in diameter on agar.

Chemolithoautotrophic growth in the presence of H2, CO2 and thiosulfate; chemoorganotrophic growth on formate, formamide, D(-)- and L(+)-lactate, glucose, starch, casamino acids, peptone, gelatine, casein, meat extract, yeast extract and extracts of eu- and archaebacterial cells, with sulfate, sulfur, sulfite and thiosulfate but not S° as electron acceptors.
H2 (up to 6 μmol/ml) and traces of methane (up to 0.1 μmol/ ml) are formed during growth.
Cell envelope consists of an S° layer composed of subunits in hexagonal array, containing a periodate-Schiff-positive polypeptide.
Factor 420- and methanopterin-like compounds present, but no coenzyme M (CoM) and no factor 430.
Adenosine triphosphate sulfurylase, adenylylsulfate reductase and bisulfite reductase activities present in cell extract.
DNA base composition is about 46 mol% G+C.
By 16S rRNA total sequence comparisons, Archaeoglobus represents a separate branch within the archaebacreria.
Type species is Archaeogloblls fulgidus, sp. nov.
